status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. The Boston Water & Sewer Commission  (BWSC) is installing a new water main on East Sixth St. The contractor RJV is installing a 3" temporary trench repair. They use a mechanical spreader for the top course. According to the inspector the temporary trench is in good rideable condition. Later this year BWSC will come back, re dig the temporary and place a permanent repair .....using a mechanical spreader again for the final lift. The City plans on paving East Sixth St but needs to make sure it is reviewed with all utility companies. You can contact the number below for a paving update. description: I have not heard from anyone about my previous report more than a month ago on the handicapped spot at this location.  Since that report, I have never once seen a car parked there and, since I live right there, I look every day.  The guy this was set up for has been dead for at least 5 years.  It's all well and good to set up handicapped spots for people who need them, but when the spots are no longer needed, they should not be handicapped spots any more.

When will the city be doing an audit of the 'Handicap' parking spots on Endicott Street?

Staring with Endicott and North Margin, there are 4-5 spots and at least that many people who requested spots outside their apartment buildings have died or are in nursing homes, unable to drive.  

And it's been about 4-5 years since these people left Endicott Street (or died). 

Plus we've cleared them during snowstorms and no one has used them for years.
This is for Board of Appeals. How does a roof deck expansion get approved @ 163 O Street when there were more people objecting to it than were for it?

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming. You can learn more about the program at www.visionzeroboston.org/nss.
